subject: Re: [junit] Parameterized test case pattern
msgSnippet: Elliotte, I ve posted it here some time ago. Your example is missing the test name: public DataDrivenTest(int i) { super( testFoo ); this.i = i; } regards,
messageBody:
Elliotte,

I've posted it here some time ago. Your example is missing the test name:

public DataDrivenTest(int i) {
super("testFoo");
this.i = i;
}

regards,
Eugene


Elliotte Rusty Harold wrote:
> Does anyone have handy a working example of the parameterized test case
> pattern? My attempts to implement it keep failing in weird ways. There's
> something I'm just not getting about it. I'm not sure how to work around
> the lack of one of the two standard constructors.
>
> Here's a simple sample data driven test that merely tests numbers are
> positive:
>
> import junit.framework.*;
> import junit.textui.TestRunner;
>
> public class DataDrivenTest extends TestCase{
>
> int i;
>
> public DataDrivenTest(int i) {
> this.i = i;
> }
>
> public static Test suite() {
> TestSuite result = new TestSuite();
> result.addTest(new DataDrivenTest(1));
> result.addTest(new DataDrivenTest(2));
> return result;
> }
>
>
> public void testFoo() {
> assertTrue(i > 0);
> }
>
> public static void main(String[] args) {
> TestRunner.run(suite());
> }
> }
>
>
> Typical output is:
> .F.F
> Time: 0.025
> There were 2 failures:
> 1) null(DataDrivenTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
> at DataDrivenTest.main(DataDrivenTest.java:25)
> 2) null(DataDrivenTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
> at DataDrivenTest.main(DataDrivenTest.java:25)
>
> FAILURES!!!
> Tests run: 2, Failures: 2, Errors: 0
>
> What am I missing? Why does this fail?
>
>
>
